Posts.Content: just thought i'd share this.  I told my 4 year old about the fact that my strong medicine would make my hair fall out - i said it like it was a big joke and so that's what she thinks it is.. her response was - 'that's funny you'll look like grandad'  since then she has taken great pleasure in pulling out my hair and was in fact slightly disppointed that it didn't all fall out in one go! kids are great - they take their lead from you and if you can hide any anxiety from them they won't feel anxious!   good luck to all of you   xxxx
Posts.Title: Telling Young Children About Hair Loss

Posts.Content: Just thought i'd let you know about a project i have been invited to join that is open to everyone having treatment for cancer.  It is a singing group in Cardiff run by a charity called tenovus.  they are running the group on thursday evenings from 6 -8pm for 12 weeks starting next week.  It is completely free and they will pay travel expenses - even for me and i am going from exeter!  they have room for more apparently so i said i would post here, cos you ladies are so great and it would be nice to meet one or two of you! contact Rosie at   rosie.dow@tenovus.org.uk   or mail me if i can tell you anything more!   ps(they have a tv crew following them around at the moment - making a show for channel 4)

Posts.Content: this is just yet another practical idea.....have you hear of The Penny Brohn cancer care charity - they are uk based, but run residential courses for free, which include accomadation.  they have a holistic approach to dealing with a cancer diagnoses which i think might suit you.  I also know a charity in devon who can offer 4 day residential breaks for people with cancer and their carers where you will be offered the chance to talk through everything and get involved in meditation and relaxation therapies.  I know the chairman of this charity and I am SURE that given the circumstance you are in currently.....they would be able to get you onto a course if you are able to get to the uk???? both these option would give you the opportunity to meet other people going through similar trauma which can be so helpful!   xxx   will be thinking of you x
Posts.Title: Two years....!

Posts.Content: Dear Sascha rose,   I have not posted here for over 8 months, but everyday I read inspirational, desperate and everyday stories from the ladies here.  I was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma in april 2 weeks after my 40th birthday.  I have had chemo, and a mastectomy (like you an immediate recon was not a choice) and due to have radiotherapy in January.  I tell you all this simply so you know where I am coming from, not because I think it means that I have any idea how you feel….i don’t, every persons journey in this life is so personal unfortunately we can never fully understand anyone else!   Sascha, I’m sure you don’t need me to tell you – you are deeply depressed.  This feels to you that it is all about your physical self and OF COURSE that has been the trigger for how you feel.  It sounds like you have had an awful time, with not nearly enough support.  Sascha, depression can be treated, you can come out the other side, feeling mentally healthy and if you were, you would be coping better with all the physical shit that is being thrown at you, I’m not saying it would be easy, it isn’t – it’s f$$king tough.  Right now for you it feels impossible and I promise you that that is because you need some more help to stabilise your feelings.    I know that your situation is desperate with regard to getting help – is the Samaritan’s an option?   But you say you are going to talk to someone in January – you are also talking in a veiled way about suicide…..please wait. have you spoken to ANYONE other than this forum about your feelings and thinking about ending it all?  If you haven't PLEASE do!   I know I am a stranger and who am I to talk, but you have people who love you and need you – hard as it is to be here for them – try.   I don’t know you, but you are a fellow breast cancer survivor and I love you. I was compelled to post tonight in the hope that you will feel that love coming across the sea to you.  feel free to personal message me, always happy to listen xxxxx Be strong lovely lady samxxxxx
Posts.Title: Two years....!

Posts.Content: hi, my hospital put my name on a list and gave me the details of 3 local places to go to where i would be given a wig.  i was given a budget of £120 but was not allowed to use this towards a more expensive wig  which was a bit annoying.  However i have a synthetic wig, which is actually alot like hair and many people have said it is actually nicer than my real hair (i have honest friends!)  I did buy shampoo,conditioner and a wig cap and comfort strip which all came to around £50.  I wont wear it all the time as i find it a bit itchy, but good for when i go out somewhere nice.  What i did buy which i will wear alot is a clip in fringe which you can attatch to any hat, it has a fringe and a few longer tendrils at the side so can look quite convincingly like you have you  hair up under your hat.  look on you tube for a fitting video and you will see what i mean.  it is much more comfortable than a wig but frames the face better than a hat or scarf. My wig fitter trimmed the fringe but if you are wanting a bit restyle i was told not to trust anyone who is not trained in wig cutting!  I bought my wig 2 weeks after first fec as my hair was thinning.  was useful to have some hair left for colour matchingxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi annie,   My BC nurse said it was fine to take paracetomol or ibroprofen but not aspirin!  she did say not to take painkillers one after another during the 5-15 days after fec as it can mask an infection and high temperature.  so take a couple now, in four hours wait an hour and take your temperature before taking any more! hope it helps xx
Posts.Title: Ibruprofen and FEC

Posts.Content: Hi Annie,    I was diagnosed two weeks ago with invasive ductal bc which has spread to my lymph nodes.  My lump is now 5 cm and like you the first couple of weeks have been mainly dread and doubt!  I have two young children under 5 and spent a little while horrified at the idea of leaving them.  I know how you feel and that no matter what i say you will think the worse.  My oncologist described me as being on the 'slip road' to secondary cancer.  I had a CT scan last sunday and a bone scan on Wed.  Started FEC chemo on Tuesday.  For all the horror.... here is the good bit....that I hope will give you hope.   I have been symptom free so far from Chemo - a couple of mouth ulcers on the first day - resolved by washing mouth out with warm salty water 3 times a day and a small amount of fatigue early evening.  My Oncologist called me back yesterday (wanted me to wait 3 weeks for results but very helpful when i said i couldn't) to say all but one of my tests have come back clear (prob waiting for bone scan!).  When i look at my beautiful children i can accept losing a breast later in the year, losing my hair (any time soon) and anything else that comes my way.....just so long as i get to watch them grow up. Just wanted to say good luck Annie and that I have been just where you are, only a week ago and already things are so much better and I hope that they will be better for you too.   los of love   sam

Posts.Content: a simple response i suppose.....   but what have you got to lose?   You have no idea what experience the person interviewing you might have, maybe they have been through the big C themselves? or had a relative go through it.  Maybe they will see your application for what it is ....evidence that you are a brave, strong, forward thinking, positive person who never gives up.  Think that is exactly what i would think, and if there was an easy way to work around the treatment problems i would definately choose someone like that over others.  even if they can't offer you the post now, who knows what may happen in the future? they might think all the things i have said, but be unable to find a way round the time off you need, employ someone else - they might not suit and the job could become open again in  6 months... then who would be thier first choice?!  go for it!
Posts.Title: Am I crazy to think about applying for a new job?

Posts.Content: Hi Trina, Sorry to hear that your family have been having such a tough time, the world likes to kick you when your down doesn't it?  Having been recently diagnosed with breast cancer, but also watching my sister battling with lung cancer last year, I can understand how much harder it is to watch someone you love go through it.  When it's you, you at least feel like you have some element of control.  But, breast cancer is SO treatable these days that ....yes your mum has a tough journey ahead.....just like you did....but in a year or so you will both be able to look back at this difficult time and know that the journey will have made you both so much stronger.  You know that your mum has been strong for you, because she is strong,  the same is true the other way around and you will be an amazing support for her, you will understand how she is feeling better than anyone and i know that having her daughter by her side (even if you need to have a cry together) will ease her journey.   Good luck at your appointment, i'm sure  you remember how much better it all feels when you have a plan of action in place with your oncologist!   xxxxxxx
